title: FARRON’S BREXIT WARNING: Lib Dem leader tells Brussels NOT to push for second referendum
text:
But now the Remoaner has claimed suggestions the European Parliament could refuse to ratify a Brexit deal unless voters get a say on it would hurt the cause. 
He said: "I don't imagine that would actually help us get it in reality. GETTY Tim Farron has pushed for a second referendum 
"A referendum on the deal is the only way to conclude this process. The only democratic way to conclude it. 
“It's the only emotionally healthy way to conclude it. It's the only way to get closure." 
In recent days the Government has repeated warnings to peers not to try to ambush the Brexit Bill when it returns to the Lords next week. Brexit: Which parts of the UK had the majority vote? Fri, February 17, 2017 Much of the North East of the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union including Sunderland, Gateshead, Darlington, Durham, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, Stockton, Redcar and Cleveland, North Tyneside and South Tyneside, and Northumberland. Newcastle was the only borough to vote to remain. Getty Images 1 of 8 GREAT YARMOUTH: The town of Great Yarmouth on the East Coast of England voted by 72% to leave the European Union. A referendum on the deal is the only way to conclude this process. The only democratic way to conclude it. Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron 
But ignoring the Prime Minister, Mr Farron said he wanted the 102-strong Lib Dem bloc in the upper chamber to vote against it unless Theresa May promised to hold another referendum. 
He said: “I take the view that if the vote is about whether the British people are given the democratic right to vote on the deal, or have to live with a stitch-up, then we should use our presence in both Houses to ensure that." 
Yet when the Brexit bill passed the Commons, two of the nine Lib Dem MPs defied Mr Farron's stance and voted it through. GETTY Mr Farron wanted 102 Lib Dem peers to vote against Brexit PA Two of the nine Lib Dem MPs defied Mr Farron's stance 
Now the leftie leader has warned MEPs to stop pushing for a second referendum - as he believes the assertive measures from the EU could harm the overall negotiations and leave Britain swinging without any exit deals in place. 
Fellow leading Remain campaigner, and former Labour shadow foreign secretary, Hilary Benn, also said a referendum push by the European Parliament would backfire. 
Mr Benn, who chairs the Commons Brexit Committee, said: "My own view is that it would be most unwise of the European Parliament to seek to attach such a condition. 
"I don't see any evidence at all that the British people, I'm sorry to say, have changed their mind." Related videos 
But prominent Leave advocate, and ex-justice secretary, Michael Gove claimed there would not be a majority to support any new referendum push. 
And he said any “talk of a second referendum invites, almost, a bad deal.” 
He added: "It invites the European Union's negotiators to give us something that would automatically be thought of as substandard and which would be likely to trigger unhappiness in a second referendum. 
"It would be counter-productive from every point of view." Related articles
